hereditary_base_notation.definition: Write number n in base b where all exponents also written in base b recursively

formal_construction.step_1: Write n in base b: n = Σ a_i·b^{k_i} where 0 ≤ a_i < b
formal_construction.step_2: Write each exponent k_i in base b
formal_construction.step_3: Recursively apply to all exponents appearing

hereditary_base_notation.uniqueness: Hereditary representation in base b unique for each n

construction.G_0: Start with n in hereditary base 2
construction.G_{k+1}: From G_k: (1) Change base to k+3, (2) Subtract 1

formal_algorithm.step_1: Write m in hereditary base b
formal_algorithm.step_4: Set m to new value, b := b+1

inevitable_termination.mystery: Why does subtraction overcome base increase?

mapping_to_ordinals.key_insight: Hereditary base representation naturally maps to ordinal notation

construction.method: Replace base b with ω in hereditary representation
construction.formal: If n = Σ a_i·b^{f_i(b)} then map to Σ a_i·ω^{f_i(ω)}

cantor_normal_form.definition: Every ordinal α < ε₀ uniquely expressible as α = ω^{β₁} + ... + ω^{βₙ} where β₁ ≥ ... ≥ βₙ
cantor_normal_form.significance: Makes ordinal structure of numbers explicit

proof_outline.step_1: Associate ordinal α_k with k-th term G_k
proof_outline.step_4: Therefore sequence must reach α_n = 0 for some finite n

lemma_1.statement: Changing base b to b+1 in hereditary representation increases value
lemma_1.proof: Each b^k becomes (b+1)^k ≥ b^k, with equality only if k=0
lemma_1.conclusion: Base change operation is monotone increasing

lemma_2.statement: Corresponding ordinal unchanged by base change
lemma_2.proof: α independent of base (defined via ω)

proof.case_1: If last term ≥ 1, subtract 1 decreases coefficient
proof.case_2: If last term = ω^β, becomes sum of ω^γ with γ < β
proof.both_cases: Ordinal strictly smaller in lexicographic order

main_argument.well_ordering: No infinite descending sequence of ordinals

epsilon_zero_necessity.definition: ε₀ = first ordinal satisfying ε₀ = ω^{ε₀}
epsilon_zero_necessity.requirement: Induction up to ε₀ needed for proof
epsilon_zero_necessity.PA_limit: PA only proves induction up to recursive ordinals << ε₀

why_ordinals_decrease.intuition: Subtraction 'eats away' from bottom of ordinal tower

mechanism.base_increase: Makes number larger but ordinal stays same
mechanism.subtraction: Reduces ordinal by removing smallest term

kirby_paris_theorem.statement: Goodstein's Theorem is unprovable in Peano Arithmetic (PA)
